descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for Wills Royal Cigarettes, two men and a woman are sitting together. The men hold fishing rods and are smoking. One of the men is lighting the other man's cigarette. The woman is about to pour something out of a thermos flask into a cup. In the foreground a packet of Wills Royal cigarettes can be seen.

statutory warning CIGARETTE SMOKING IS INJURIOUS TO HEALTH

description-en: On this advertisement for Wills Royal Cigarettes, two men and a woman are sitting together. The men hold fishing rods and are smoking. One of the men is lighting the other man's cigarette. The woman is about to pour something out of a thermos flask into a cup. In the foreground a packet of Wills Royal cigarettes can be seen. (gs/sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: /img_0010.jpg

explanatory comments/crosstagging: According to Erving Goffman in his study "Gender Advertisements" the position of the man and the woman on the image points to the fact that he has a higher status. It is very common to portray men 1) taller than women, 2) while helping the woman in some kind. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Richard Dyer explains in his book "white" that gender portrayals in most still and moving images are unconsciously informed by Christian iconography. In Christianity women were seen as the purer sex, whereas men have a dark inner core that they have to overcome during their lifetime. On images this is mirrored in the fact that females are often lighter than men. Not only in skin colour, but also in the colour of their dress. (la)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The gender roles, namely the men fishing and smoking and the woman providing drinks and not fishing, are pretty clear in this advertisement. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the Indian context cigarette advertising during almost the entire 20th century featured distinctively Western woman as it was considered to be indecent for Indian woman to smoke in public. Depicting an Indian woman on an ad for cigarettes would most likely have had a negative effect. See also the article on early Indian advertsing by Javeer Masood on Tasveerghar. (la)
